content: Ebola virus disease (Ebola, or EVD) is a severe, often fatal disease first detected in the Democratic Republic of the Congo in 1976. It is spread through contact with infected bodily fluids and has caused a large outbreak in West Africa, with nearly 10,000 cases and almost 5,000 deaths reported as of late October. As of late October, nearly 10,000 people have contracted Ebola virus disease (EVD), with almost 5,000 deaths reported. WHO estimates actual cases may be higher due to weak surveillance systems in neighboring countries. Mali reported its first EVD case on October 23, prompting WHO to send a team for assistance.
